examples.input_text: How to use BLOB store in CrateDB? and what are the benefits?
examples.output_text_a:
To use BLOB store in CrateDB, you can persistently store and retrieve BLOB data such as pictures, videos, or large unstructured files in a fully distributed cluster solution. The benefits include efficient replication and distribution of binary data across multiple nodes in a cluster, simplifying the management of data storage as a whole. 

Sources:
- [Using Crate as a BLOB Store](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore)
- [CrateDB Features - BLOB Data](https://cratedb.com/product/features/blob-data)
examples.output_text_b:
To use BLOB store in CrateDB, you can persistently store and retrieve BLOBs such as pictures, videos, or large unstructured files in a fully distributed cluster solution. CrateDB provides BLOB storage for this purpose, allowing you to store binary data in a table that is automatically sharded and replicated across your cluster. 

The benefits of using BLOB store in CrateDB include efficient replication of files across multiple nodes in a cluster, advanced features for optimal distribution, and simplification of data management by applying the same replication and sharding rules to both the blob store and other data in the database. 

Sources: 
- [Using Crate as a BLOB Store](https://cratedb.com/blog/using-crate-as-a-blobstore)
- [CrateDB Features: Blob Data](https://cratedb.com/product/features/blob-data)

examples.input_text: How AWS marketplace works, and why I cannot see deployment in my account?
examples.output_text_a:
AWS Marketplace allows users to subscribe to services like CrateDB Cloud and deploy clusters. When subscribing to CrateDB Cloud's offering on AWS Marketplace, it can take up to 10 minutes for the subscription to be confirmed and usable in the CrateDB Cloud console. The hourly usage of the service on AWS Marketplace is billed directly by Amazon, not Crate.io. If you cannot see the deployment in your account immediately after subscribing, it may take some time for the subscription to be confirmed. You can refer to the CrateDB Cloud documentation for more information on how to subscribe and deploy via AWS Marketplace. 

Sources: 
- [CrateDB Cloud Documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/deploy/marketplace/subscribe-aws.html)
- [CrateDB Cloud Blog](https://cratedb.com/blog/run-etl-with-astro-and-cratedb-cloud-in-30min-fully-up-in-the-cloud)
examples.output_text_b:
Based on the provided context, AWS Marketplace works by allowing users to subscribe to services like CrateDB Cloud through their platform. When subscribing to CrateDB Cloud through AWS Marketplace, it can take up to 10 minutes for the subscription to be confirmed and usable in the CrateDB Cloud console. The hourly usage of the service is billed directly by Amazon, not by Crate.io. If you cannot see the deployment in your account immediately after subscribing, it may be due to the confirmation process taking some time. You can check the status of your subscription and deployment after a few minutes. 

Sources:
- [CrateDB Cloud AWS Marketplace Tutorial](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/deploy/marketplace/subscribe-aws.html)
- [CrateDB Cloud AWS Marketplace Tutorial - Confirmation Time](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/deploy/marketplace/subscribe-aws.html#signup-aws-to-cluster)

examples.input_text: What are edge regions and how to use them?
examples.output_text_a: Edge regions are components that need to be updated regularly to receive new features, bug fixes, and security updates. To create a custom edge region, users can go to the Regions tab in the CrateDB Cloud Console, fill out a name for the region, and click on the "Create edge region" button. Once created, users can deploy a cluster from within their custom edge region by going to the Regions tab of the Organization overview and selecting the custom region. More information on how to work with CrateDB Edge can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/edge/managed-kubernetes.html#edge-providers).
examples.output_text_b: Edge regions are components that need to be updated regularly to receive new features, bug fixes, and security updates. To create a custom Edge region, users can go to the Regions tab in the CrateDB Cloud Console, fill out a name for the region, and click on the Create edge region button. Once created, users can deploy a cluster from within their custom Edge region by going to the Regions tab of the Organization overview and following the instructions provided. If the region is outdated, users will see an Upgrade this Edge region button next to the region, which will provide a command to update the Edge region. This command can be pasted into the environment where the Edge cluster is deployed to upgrade it. More information on how to work with CrateDB Edge can be found [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/cloud/en/latest/tutorials/edge/managed-kubernetes.html#edge-providers).

examples.input_text: how to alter table and add vector type field that allows for KNN search?
examples.output_text_a:
To alter a table and add a vector type field that allows for KNN search in CrateDB, you can refer to the official CrateDB documentation on data types. The FLOAT_VECTOR data type in CrateDB implements a vector store and the k-nearest neighbour (kNN) search algorithm to find vectors that are similar to a query vector. 

You can follow the instructions provided in the documentation to create tables with multiple data types, select the most similar products based on vector search with KNN_MATCH, and perform other operations related to vector data types and KNN search.

Source: [CrateDB Documentation on Data Types](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/5.6/general/ddl/data-types.html)
examples.output_text_b: To alter a table and add a vector type field that allows for KNN search in CrateDB, you can refer to the official CrateDB documentation on creating tables with multiple data types, including the FLOAT_VECTOR data type which supports KNN_MATCH for k-nearest neighbour search. Here is the link to the documentation: [CrateDB - Creating Tables with Multiple Data Types](https://cratedb.com/solutions/multi-model-database).

examples.input_text: create table with fields ID, name, vector, and index vector field for KNN search?
examples.output_text_a:
To create a table in CrateDB with fields ID, name, vector, and index the vector field for KNN search, you can follow the example provided in the CrateDB documentation:

```sql
CREATE TABLE my_table (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name STRING,
  vector FLOAT_VECTOR(2),
  INDEX vector_vector_idx USING PLAIN_BLOOMFILTER (vector)
);
```

This SQL statement creates a table called `my_table` with the specified fields and creates an index on the `vector` field for efficient KNN search.

You can find more information about creating tables with vector data types in CrateDB [here](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/domain/ml/index.html#ml).
examples.output_text_b:
To create a table with fields ID, name, vector, and index the vector field for KNN search, you can refer to the following SQL code:

```sql
CREATE TABLE my_table (
  ID INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name STRING,
  vector FLOAT_VECTOR(2),
  INDEX vector USING PLAIN
);
```

This code snippet defines a table called `my_table` with the specified fields and creates an index on the `vector` field for KNN search. This example assumes the vector data has 2 dimensions, but you can adjust the dimensions as needed based on your data.

You can find more information about creating tables with vector data and KNN search in CrateDB in the [CrateDB documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/domain/ml/index.html#ml).

examples.input_text: How to create ID field that is autoincremented?
examples.output_text_a:
Based on the provided context and sources, the recommended approach to create an ID field that is autoincremented in CrateDB is to use the `_id` system column as a primary key. This column contains a unique identifier for each record, and it is deterministic, meaning that two individual records in different tables with the same primary key definition and values will also have identical `_id` values. Additionally, documents living in tables without a primary key are assigned a unique auto-generated ID automatically when created.

Sources:
- [CrateDB - Performance Inserts Tuning](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/performance/inserts/tuning.html)
- [CrateDB - Storage Consistency Concepts](https://cratedb.com/docs/crate/reference/en/4.8/concepts/storage-consistency.html)
examples.output_text_b:
Based on the provided sources, it seems that in CrateDB, if your data does not have a natural primary key, you can use the `_id` system column as a primary key, which is automatically generated and unique for each record. This eliminates the need to manually create an autoincremented ID field. 

Source: [CrateDB Documentation](https://cratedb.com/docs/guide/performance/inserts/tuning.html)
